text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The good news is just so you hear it, is half the guys are cured at five years and then if you look ten years down – Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the line, nine out of ten guys are still alive if you go through the hormones and surgery, hormones and radiation, okay. Patient: Sure, uh hum. Doctor: You may be fighting prostate cancer, but you’re alive. Family Member: Right. Patient: Right, right, yeah. Doctor: So, so I just want to take a moment and pause and say we’ve got a serious problem here but it’s not a death sentence a year from now or two years from now. Patient: Right, right, right. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Perspective.

text: Family Member: Is that something that could possibly happen in this case? Doctor: With the hormone therapy—yes. Family Member: With the hormone therapy—yes. Doctor: It happens frequently. Doctor, it’s always good to see you. And thank you for your advice. And we’re going to follow your lead. Doctor: And I’ll follow your lead. We’ll help each other. Patient: Yes sir. Yes sir. Now, do I need to go to K___ to get a prescription? Doctor: You’ll wait to hear from us. L___ will help us to do that. L___ will help us to get the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. text: Family Member: Okay. With what? Doctor: P-S-M-A. Family Member: Oh. P-S-M-A. Doctor: Which is, uh, antigen that a lot of the prostate cancers produce. So what it- what that treatment does, is it attaches to that antigen on the cancer cells and releases the radiation right where the cancer is at. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That is the idea behind it. For that, though, first, what we have to do is make sure that your cancer is actually expressing that antigen. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And that is a specialized scan that is done either in Texas or in New York. Family Member: Yeah. We talked about that. Doctor: So you would have to go over there to get that scan before we can even decide if you should get the study or not. Family Member: So he’d have to have some blood work? Is it a blood draw? Is it, uh-? Doctor: For what?

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Oxycodone immediate release five milligrams. Patient: No, that’s been set up for ten milligrams, and that’s as needed now after it’s been about two weeks since my radiation. Doctor: So it’s that ten milligram pill you take? Patient: No it’s two fives. Doctor: Oh, yeah. The OxyContin? And the OxyContin is thirty milligrams twice a day? Patient: Once a day; I’m taking it once a day now. Doctor: Once a day. Patient: Yeah, I’m taking it at night, so you know to get ahead of the pain. But it’s been pretty good. I haven’t been in much hip pain lately, hardly at all. Doctor: The Simvastatin twenty milligrams a day. That’s your Zocor. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: Your Flomax or Tamsulosin once a day? Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - your PSA was a fourteen in September and then it was twenty-eight January. So in a four-month period your PSA went up one hundred percent. It doubled. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So based on that trajectory, if I had to guess, your PSA is still at the same place, so to speak, it will take about half that amount of time for your PSA to go about fifty percent. So if it goes - you’re expected to go up fifty percent … for a year, two years Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So that’s the general, overall, design of the trial. And um because the trial involves radiation therapy being delivered by a radiology oncologist. And would and the ORIOLE study as they call it, is being run by one of the radiology oncologists called Dr. T. You’ll see his name here. And, the way that we would precede, if you wanted me to, is to after we have this conversation… to give you the consent form, read it very carefully. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Um to arrange a consultation, or a timely consultation with Dr. T in his clinic, which is in the building. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And, on that particular day you would have read out any particular information about the trial and issue questions for him and his team. Um, and if those questions aren’t answered to your satisfaction go ahead and do that. Then after that you’ve basically completed the screening for randomization. Okay. So although the study is a randomized study, it’s not a blinded study. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But in the case of radiotherapy versus therapy,

text: Family Member: Well there’s good choices you can make. Doctor: Yeah. (Laughs) Patient: You know and a lot more bad ones. Doctor: That is true. Huh, this makes a lot of sense now. Okay. text: Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Or my sense is the other thing is, you know, if time was short, I probably would sort of step back and sort of just focus on, you know, good days. Um. So I would sit there on the fence. I’m not ready to give up on myself. I wanna try something versus -- hhh this has all been too much. (Pause4sec) Patient: If it, it, it extends my, my time that I have to wait for a real cure then maybe it’s worth it. Doctor: Well, that reality is pretty slim. You know, we’ve been working on this awhile, and I’m not sure that a cure is gonna just pop up in the next six months, nine months. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And again, we often, er, don’t have drugs that resurrect people. Uh. You can hope. I hope and pray as well. Uh. The reality is, you know, you can keep pluggin’ along. Uh, so I think you’re eligible because you’re physically well enough to get through this. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? And you have the desire, uh, but there may be a point where I think you maybe too sick or your labs don’t work, or there are other things that suggest that more therapy is not the right thing. Patient: I see. Doctor: I will say that to you. It may not be what you want to hear. Patient: It’s the reality. (Pause) Doctor: As long as the quality’s good. That’s my worry. Okay? You can get extra time, but if it sucks, then it’s (not awful)

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
